To my understanding the laser is just focusing large amounts of energy in one stream, which in turn burns or melts whats in front of it. If you where using one to say make a hole for a support the laser would heat the rock until it became molten, given it is powerful enough. It may just be me but I'd rater dig the material out than make a dangerous molten mess. That being said things are always advancing so who knows what will be done in the future.
That's actually a very good question.
Btw, ask google e.g. for "laser ablation" if you want to know more about evaporation using lasers ;-)

Well, with last laser you can't only melt or burn matter, but you can also evaporize material. Or even just heat if you'd wanted to. You may think of a laser as just a form of energy that you bring in. The effect that it causes here is primarily a function of energy density, absorption, heat capacity and thermal conductivity of the target material. Digging deep is well possible, though you have to deal with vapor in the beam line of sight, beam divergence, etc.
l love the end, MY EYE AND MY FINGER NOOOOOOO!!!!! 2:20
That would require an unnecessary amount of power, unless you were digging through something REALLY hard, or you needed to dig REALLY fast.
Holland!!!!!!!
Melting/burning a kilogram of dirt requires insane amounts of energy compared to lifting the same amount of dirt from ground. So using lasers would not be practical.

Unhealthy, yes. Ill-advised, sure. A bit stupid, yes.

you mean vaporizing the dirt?
sure, it's possible, but the amount of energy it would require would be phenomenal.. and a complete waste.

Lasers aren't the answer to earth-moving.
I don't believe they could actually burn right through rock/dirt, etc.
That light hurt my eyes through the screen. Just imagine if you weren't wearing those goggles...

That's not really how digging works from my understanding... if you look at any bucket wheel excavator or even a simple metal drill, you'd find that not only they cut into the material, more importantly they extract material away in the opposite direction of where they are digging, a super powerful laser would do nothing but melt the rocks, creating lava that remains in the hole, potentially blocking any fresh rock to be exposed to the laser beam..

I'm just a physics student, but from what I've learned, while you could use lasers to ignite or vaporize biomatter, it would be tremendously inefficient due to the huge cost and energy inefficiency due to heat losses of high-powered lasers (see the heatsink on the laser they're using). Plus, inorganic matter likely wouldn't burn and any shiny objects may cause unpredictable and dangerous reflections. Finally, you'd still have to dig up whatever isn't vaporized.
